boardgame.name: Grizimilak
boardgame.description:
From Overview:

Establishing a settlement in or near swamplands is a difficult task at best. Settlers have to contend with disease, vermin, flooding, predators, and a host of other conditions. While many of these can be overcome through perseverance, some obstacles are insurmountable. Grizimilaks are one such case. More than one settlement has been abandoned because of these well-meaning nuisances, often spreading the problem to other regions.

Grizimilaks are overly friendly swamp dwellers that believe they are of gnomish descent (a claim refuted by any sane gnome). Their short, almost goblinoid appearance, gnomish affinity, and constant trails of grime have earned this prolific race many derogatory names. They may be called sludge imps, grimekin, or hundreds of other names. They are most commonly called gnomblin, to the chagrin of both gnomes and goblins. Of course, high-spirited grizimilaks are oblivious to the insult.

Grizimilaks breed at an alarming rate, and have a surprisingly long lifespan. A single grizimilak, whether offering assistance or devising pranks, is a nuisance. In large numbers, the race reaches the levels of natural disaster. The race is very hardy, making an infestation nearly impossible to get rid of. Once a grizimilak adopts a person or a settlement, the end quickly follows.

boardgame.name: Jhardwyn
boardgame.description:
From Overview:

A fractured people, the jhardwyn are both much less and much more than other races. The jhardwyn are an amalgamation of myriad races, possessed of matchless potential. They have lost the cultural building abilities available to most races, forced to constantly wander.

The jhardwyn are the result of a cataclysmic fusion of a wide range of planar races. This event imbued the jhardwyn with a deep well of untapped potential, while consuming their civilization. So great is this power that the close proximity of jhardwyn to one another quickly consumes them. Even the countless worlds yearn for the power within the jhardwyn, consuming the essence of any jhardwyn who ceases to travel. Unable to plant the seeds of a new culture, the jhardwyn are perpetual travelers, forever visitors among other races.

Yet, the jhardwyn are an optimistic people, viewing their current misfortune as a step on the path to becoming something greater.

boardgame.name: Ka Ngrej
boardgame.description:
From Overview:

The term KaNgrej serves a dual purpose, referring to a formal race and a constantly expanding menagerie of sub-races. The prime race is the oldest, most commonly encountered archetype, referred to simply as the KaNgrej. The vast array of sub-races possesses formal racial names, such as VaeRdin, IthWra, and TaZoel, seldom referred to simply as KaNgrej.

KaNgrej as a species is similar to humanity, with an ability to thrive in virtually any environment. Where humanity commonly reshapes the environment for comfort, the KaNgrej readily evolve, adapting to new environments over several generations. Rapid adaptability accounts for the great diversity among KaNgrej sub-races, being well adapted to their native environments. However, the prime KaNgrej are more often inclined to follow the approach of humanity, sculpting the environment into habitable settlements, harvesting precious resources, forging powerful nations.

boardgame.name: Lidaem
boardgame.description:
From Overview:

The subtle touch of their political guidance is all but undetectable in desert cities. They mix freely with the social elite, the true extent of their influence going undetected by their peers. The exotic lidaem are both dependent on and separate from other desert cultures.

The lidaem are a race of female humanoids that become ingrained fixtures of desert cultures. An obvious comparison of the lidaem is made with amazons. Beyond the fact that both groups are composed entirely of females, there is little similarity between the two. Amazons are sub-races of other races. The lidaem are a proper race. Lidaem require males from other humanoid races to propagate the species, but always produce pureblooded lidaem. Lidaem shy away from the physical pursuits preferred by amazons, preferring to develop their psionic and social skills.

Yet, like amazons, lidaem possess a distinct culture. The home of the lidaem, Acobil, exists on a plane separate from the cultures they adopt. Acobil and the lidaem race are the priorities of the race, not allegiances to adopted cultures. Lidaem closely guard the secrets of their culture and Acobil. This hidden culture is maintained in small covens of traveling lidaem. Wherever one lidaem treads, so to does their culture.

boardgame.name: Super Mario GAME
Das Super Mario Spiel
boardgame.description:
The game's theme is based on the GameBoy Version of Nintendo's "Super Mario Land" from 1989.

Story
Princess Daisy of Sarasaland was kidnapped by the monster Tatanga. Super Mario and Luigi travel through the kingdoms of Birabuto, Muda and Easton to reach the kingdom of Tschai where the princess is held. The first player who reaches Tschai and beats the evil Tatanga and the other players frees the princess and wins the game.

Contents:

1 Board
8 Figures in 4 different Colors
1 Dice
60 Cards


Flow of Play
Each player has two figures (Mario and Luigi). Players roll a die to determine how far one of their figures can move. The board has some special places like traps and questionmarks. Traps cast the figure some spaces back. Questionmarks let the player draw one of the cards. On these player may find enemies which can be fought by a die roll or special items which let them avoid traps or enemies. The player who reaches the final place with both figures has to defeat the last enemy and the other players by rolling the dice.

boardgame.name: Mneumra
boardgame.description:
From Overview:

The mneumra are living vessels for the essence of those ravaged by plague. Drawn to sorrow and loss, they are precursors to the coming of disease and death.

The first mneumra was a true construct, though the process of its creation has been lost to time. The events directly preceding and following it creation are passed down to each new generation of mneumrae. In the distant past, a great artificer remembered simply as Father lived in a realm beset by an unnatural plague. His family succumbed to the ravages of the spreading disease. The last of his children, his youngest child, was the last, fading fast. In a desperate gambit to save his child, Father made a pact with powerful nature spirits. The essence of the rapidly fading son was bound with potent arcane and natural energies, funneled into a waiting vessel. This construct was Father's greatest work, a piece of unrivaled craftsmanship. The memory of the child was preserved as the body failed.

As a condition of the pact, Father was obligated to preserve the essences of as many other sufferers of the plague as possible. Over the following months, Father traveled the crumbling kingdom, fulfilling his pledge. Father’s vessels were limited, however, only able to aid the youngest sufferers. During this time the term mneumra was coined by the parents of the young whose essences were preserved. The name was a combination of the words for “memory” and “urn”. Father saved many before being forced into seclusion, being afflicted by the plague. As the disease scoured all life from the land, only the mneumra were spared, left to rebuild.

Since that time, the mneumra have wandered, drawn to the first signs of plague. They continue to honor the memory of Father, preserving the essences of plague stricken young, final remembrances of their passing.

boardgame.name: Pergothi
boardgame.description:
From Overview:

Once a lighthearted race, the pergothi are now a jaded people. Their ability to create artistic masterworks is overshadowed by their rigorous military skill. The pergothi have a solemn duty to protect all aquatic creatures from those who dwell beyond the waves.

The pergothi once existed in far greater numbers. They were a race of artists responsible for wondrous pieces of aquatic art. Their creations joined worked items seamlessly with the natural world. These masterpieces were sought by those from both below and above the waves.

But the appetites of air-breathers are well known for their ravenousness. They demanded greater works. Over the course of a single century, their frenetic quest looted the treasures of the pergothi. But this was not the worst blow to the pergothi. Many airbreathing races viewed the exotic pergothi with the same avarice as their art. Those pergothi who did not flee were stripped from their home below the waves, becoming little more than pets. Most of these pergothi quickly withered in captivity.

Pergothi went unseen beneath the waves for centuries. When they finally returned, they were no longer the genteel artisans of old. They were a force to be reckoned with, possessing a divine mandate to drive air-breathers from beneath the oceans.

boardgame.name: Rin
boardgame.description:
From Overview:

Appearances can be deceiving. Most people know this, but still fall into the trap of not questioning too deeply. In some cases, this failure can have a high cost, such as when dealing with the rin.

Rin are fully aware of what others believe. It is easy to see the massive frame and assume it belongs to a hulking brute of limited intelligence. Rin do nothing to dissuade this misconception. In fact, rin intentionally perpetuate the stereotype that they are ignorant, solitary, short-lived beasts.

In truth, rin are cunning trappers who may live for centuries hidden under swampy waters. The cultural xenophobia of the rin is the only thing keeping these intelligent, powerful creatures from pursuing conquest.

boardgame.name: Xeshaal
boardgame.description:
From Overview:

Eyeless they see. Earless they hear. Their hunger feeds the growing emptiness that is Vahhsh.

Superficially, xeshaals resemble exotic humanoids. From a distance, their tattooed bodies resemble alabaster-skinned humans. Their primitive garb makes them easily mistakable for albino barbarians with white hair that sways without wind.

Once close enough to make out their physical features, however, all illusions fall aside. What was mistaken for hair coalesces into tendrils of flesh. The facial features are painted on in a crude mockery of eyes, ears, nose and mouth. Hidden underneath is featureless flesh.

The eyes do not linger on the empty face, instead drawn to the gaping maws on their palms. Black liquid drips between the teeth, quickly dissipating.

Xeshaals are a truly alien race. They have no shared ancestry with any other race or creature, aliens among the races of the multi-verse. They are living portals to the plane of Vahhsh. Neither good nor evil, their only purpose is to experience and
feed the plane.

boardgame.description:
User Summary: Game Chef 2010 Design Competition Submission.

Subtitle: What Will Your Life Story Be?

Author Blurb:
So what is this game all about?
Well its a story game about life.

With a group of friends you get to make up a set of stories about people. These won’t be detailed sagas. Instead we’ll dip into the lives of these characters at key points in their lives and find out a little about who they are and how they think. Some of the stories might be amusing, some sad, but they should all tell us something about the characters.

The most important part of the game though is seeing what these people leave behind:

How does the world change as a result of their actions?
How are they remembered?
How did they make a difference?

User Summary: Game Chef 2010 Design Competition Submission.

Author Blurb:
Starting the game. If you have a group of 4 or more players (3 will do in a pinch, and more than 6-7 may feel unsatisfying), a copy of these rules, the various Question Cards, and a couple of hours of free time, great, you have everything you need to play this game. World Riddle should be a koan - the answer to the question is neither important nor fixed, nor does it need to make any sense. The important part of the game is how the players reach the answer and what it reveals to them about the characters they create and about themselves.

Author Blurb:
The Chaos Lords and the Desert of Death, from here on referred to as Chaos Lords, is a beer and pretzels, completely over-the-top, science fantasy role playing game that should not be taken too seriously. What exactly does that mean?
● Beer and Pretzels game: Simple mechanics, simple characters, almost no math beyond basic addition and dividing by two, and a setting that fully accepts unexpected characters.

boardgame.name: Symbolon
boardgame.description:
Author Blurb:
User Summary: Submission for the Game Chef 2010 Competition.

Author Blurb:
A Journey to Fall
Not knowing is worth a Question

You asked a Question. Of someone. Yourself. World. Life. Doesn't really matter. It has been pressing your soul and now it's out there. No taking it back. You've asked it. Now there's a fragment of a street map drawn on your palm, in ink. Like an imprint from a cheap newspaper, but there.

It's here, in the City. Your Answer waits. So start moving. Through the streets. Through time. Step of the building already. Fall. Fly.

Can't stay on the Edge forever. There are too many things too be said. Your Skin knows. Watch it. Follow as the marks are written. Only... this is Your Question and Your Answer... So who's writing?

The City is a construct providing Answers. It superimposes itself on any given surrounding, mimicing time period and space. Once unfolded, it ensures both obstacles and guidance. Feeding on lost Pledges of those that were here before, it exists solely to react to Questions.

boardgame.name: NotChess
boardgame.description:
NotChess is a game on an 8X* board that is a checker-like game, using pieces called Alternators. Any piece is able to be captured by an opponent whose piece moves onto the square of the piece being captured. (By replacement)

The objective is to become the only player remaining on the board.
An Alternator moves as a chess knight when moving from a white square but it moves as a short range chess rook when moving from a black square. A player starts with six pieces on the rank closest to them.

boardgame.name: Elephant Checkers
boardgame.description:
Elephant Checkers is basically Turkish Checkers played on an Xiangqi Board with a extra rules and additional pieces.
Each player starts with 24 pieces (soldiers). The goal of the game is to leave your opponent with no moves (capturing all of their pieces does this nicely), or to promote an Elephant (a promoted Soldier) to King on the point in the center of your opponent's fortress.

As in many checker games captures are obligatory, and a player must choose the move with the most possible captures.
Soldiers move one square forward or horizontally. They may also capture an enemy piece (or a series of them) by jumping over it to a vacant junction beyond.

Once across the river a Soldier may move two squares or capture pieces two squares ahead or to the side, or capture a piece an adjacent piece and land two squares past it.

When a Soldier reaches the far side it promotes to an Elephant (the name source).
Elephants may move to any vacant junction (since Xiangqi is played on the points, not sqaures) vertically or horizontally. They capture by jumping over an enemy piece, and can continue to any empty square beyond the capture.

"They may promote to King and win the game if on the Throne point in the center of the opposing fortress, but that move counts as a non-capturing move, and can not be made when there is a capture available."

User Summary: Game Chef 2010 Design Contest Submission

Author Blurb:
Each player writes down 2-3 wishes on seperate index cards. The wishes can be anything he wishes had been, would be, or could be.

All wishes go into a bowl, and each player draws one at random, which then becomes the Dream which drives his character.

Each character exists in his own story. Characters do not need to exist in the same place, time frame, or even the same universe. Each player decides who his character is and when and where that character lives. He may reword his character's wish as seems appropriate for the character and setting.

The connection between the characters is in a theme that runs through all of their stories. Think of this theme as the the Title of a collection of short stories, each story featuring one of the characters in play. Players may choose a Title from the list, or agree on a new Title more appropriate to the Dreams forming their stories.

boardgame.name: Planetouched Feats: Secrets of the Inner Planes
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

Planetouched feats are feats that a character may acquire after having spent a certain period of time on a plane of existence which is not the dimension she was born into. Oftentimes, a character might pick up some essence of the plane she has been to, or learn some new ability that would not otherwise available if she had not interacted with the denizens of a particular realm.

boardgame.description:
From the website:

The Scenario:
One year ago, Robert Killingsworth bought the farm. Six months later, he was dead - leaving his widow, Elizabeth, to tend to their fledgling winery and vineyard on the outskirts of California's wine country. With mounting debts and no clue as to how to run a business, Elizabeth is desperate to sell the farm and recoup her losses. The fierce drought and shaky economy, however, have left the Killingsworth Farm on the market for far too long.

One early autumn day, six people passed through the gates of Killingsworth Farm to see Elizabeth - one of them, a cold-blooded Killer...

Those Present at Killingsworth Farm:

Michael Nightshade: This real estate developer from New York arrived unannounced with plans to buy Killingsworth Farm and develop it into a low-cost housing community. His boss ordered him to obtain the Killingsworth land at any price…

Dr. Chelsea Barren: After suffering a nervous breakdown, this psychiatrist and best-selling author moved to Northern California to relax… but she moved next door to the Killingsworths instead.

Vicki D'Adly: Elizabeth's estranged sister from New Jersey, she and her husband were traveling on vacation when Vicki decided to drop by Killingsworth Farm for a visit… a surprise visit.

Norman D'Adly: A real estate broker from New Jersey and husband to Vicki, Norman is trying to salvage his job and his marriage while traveling across the country on vacation.

Kathryn Lawless: Best friend to Elizabeth, this local librarian and historian has a flare for the eccentric. She lives down the road with her 15 cats and loves true crime - especially the mysterious, unsolved death of Robert Killingsworth

Enrique Graves: This young drifter wandered onto Killingsworth Farm just as Robert and Elizabeth were moving in. Elizabeth took a liking to Enrique and he has lived on the farm ever since - tending to the fields… among other things.

Which of these people has a secret worth killing for? Come to Killingsworth Farm and find out before it is too late!

디제이맥스 포터블 핫튠즈
boardgame.description:
User Summary

DJ Max Portable: Hot Tunes is a compilation music video game for the PSP. The game includes songs and features from DJ Max Portable and DJ Max Portable 2, and was designed to be a beginner-friendly version of the games.

Hot Tunes allows players to choose from a number of different songs. Each song has a preset note configuration that scrolls from the top of the screen, and the player must press the buttons in time to the notes in order to build combos and complete the songs. Notes can either be single points or drawn lines, the latter of which require the player to hold the button down for a period of time. Successfully hitting enough notes engages Fever Mode, which increases the score multiplier and note values.

The game is a combination of Portable and Portable 2, and features a number of different play modes. The player can choose to have songs set in 4B Lite, 6B or 8B modes, which correspond to the number of buttons present in the songs.

A limited print of 2000 Collector’s sets were produced which include a limited edition wooden case, calendar, original soundtrack, 2 booklet posters, and 8 mini posters.

boardgame.name: Virtue Cards
boardgame.description:
Virtue Cards
Attitudes and Actions of Excellence

Virtue Cards come as a standard deck of 52 poker-sized playing cards, each detailing a different Virtue.

However, the deck doesn't just contain an arbitrary list of Virtues. Instead, extensive research and experimentation has resulted in a systematic approach to classifying Virtues by several factors including Aspect, Focus, Type, & Rank.

Each Virtue Card defines the corresponding Virtue and gives a reference Bible verse along with a an easy to understand definition. Each card displays several symbols specific to the system to allow for quick visual reference. In addition, the cards have been implemented using normal suits and ranks allowing the cards to be used like a standard playing deck.

Ultimately, using the system makes learning and remembering the Virtues easy and fun as Virtue Cards can be used to play any existing card game with a "Virtuous twist" as well as games specifically designed for the system.

User Summary

Builderland is a race-against-the-clock puzzle game. The player must lead a little character named Melba across each of the side-scrolling levels. Melba doesn't stop and can't jump or climb rocks, so the player must move items on the screen to help him out: stairs, trampolines, blocks to fill pot holes. Melba also picks up any objects he walks over and the player can use these objects later.

Each level has a different code, there is a "timed pause" option (the player can freeze the game for several seconds to ponder the next moves), and a suicide option should the character becomes stuck (which is the main cause of death in the game).

boardgame.name: The DragonSlayer
boardgame.description:
The DragonSlayer is a free print and play game in which the player must enter seven lairs and slay each the beast that lives there. Each time a beast dies, the player can collect the weapon that the beast had in it's lair. The weapons are humorous and include such things as a double barreled bazooka, a rocket sword, and a tank.

The combat system is very simple. Both the player and the beast have a starting health which is decreased by modified die roll. Depending on your weapon and the beast's strength the damage may be a die roll + 2, a combination of four dice rolled together, or similar modifiers. Each lair and weapon has it's own modifier. Assuming that you survive combat, you're health is automatically reset for the next cave.

Each beast is more difficult to kill than the last (culminating with the dragon in the 7th lair), but each new weapon is more powerful so the player's combat ability increases with the game's difficulty. The game is won by slaying the dragon.

boardgame.name: Wicked Wickets
boardgame.description:
Wicked Wickets is a cricket based table game suitable for the whole family, cricketers and non-cricketers alike, and can accommodate anything from two to twenty-two players. The game involves selection, bowling, batting, and active fielding, allowing for short over fast action games through to the complex realms of strategy found in test play. Although, like with cricket itself, the basics are simple and easily learnt, it will inevitably take a lifetime to master.

No prior knowledge of cricket is needed to play the game which is suitable for the whole family and up to 22 players. In essence the side that scores the most "runs" wins, though selecting the right players, the order they play, and where they are positioned all affect the outcome of the game. The basics of Wicked Wickets are really quite simple; the bowler throws the ball, in this case the red ball shaped die, and the batsman "hits" it by throwing the buff bat-shaped die. Adding the scores together shows how far the ball goes using the long flight measure. If the batsman's score is higher than the bowlers, the ball "flies" in the air; if the bowler's score is higher than the batsman's, then it is struck along the ground. The yellow counter and dice are used to show which direction the ball goes. The short pace measure is simply used to measure the distance players move and the green die is mostly used for fielding. The game cards give the individual abilities of the players affecting how and where they are used. However, as with most games there is often more to it than first meets the eye. --From the publisher

Official website: http://www.boadiceasbackyard.com/

boardgame.name: Wit
boardgame.description:
Paraphrased from the game's instruction sheet:

A word game for two to four players, utilizing a deck of 112 cards with individual letters on them (4 of each constanant other than Z (of which there are 2) and 6 each of A,E,I,O and U). Players are dealt a hand of 9 cards. Game play consists of laying cards to form complete words, which are scored against a table.
A player's turn begins by drawing a card from either the draw pile or the top of the discard pile, then continues with the laying of whatever words the player can make with the cards in his or her hand, then finishes with the laying of an additional card to the discard pile. Players may also capture words made by other players by adding letters to the played word to form a new word.
A round ends when someone fully discards his hand by playing a word or words. The player does not need to be able to discard a card if playing all cards into words.


A later version of this game was published together with the dice game Farkel; that game has a deck half the size.

boardgame.name: Knusperhaus
La Maison de Pain d'Epice
Perníková Chaloupka Perníková Chalupka
boardgame.description:
Hansel is too greedy and wants to eat all the cookies from the roof of the witch her house. But he has to be carefull because the witch who is disguised as a pigeon will prevent him.

The board looks like a house with on top 3 places to put a card. Shuffle the deck of cards and put three cards on these locations. Then you put a pigeon figure on the roof in one of the three slots above a card. There is also a Hansel figure, place this on the table.

At his turn a player may turn over a card from the deck. If the card doesn't match the card under the pigeon nothing happens and the player may take the card. The player can turn over as many cards as he wants. If he wants to stop he can take all the cards that he has turned over. But if he turns the same card that is under the pigeon then the player has to make the sound of a pigeon and take the pigeon figure from the roof to prevent the witch from coming down. At the same time each other player may try to take the hansel figure. The first person who does this gets the first card of the open pile, and all the cards go to a discard pile. So the player who turned the cards lost all his cards (except maybe one). The witch is then put in a slot on the roof again.

A player that took Hansel by mistake has to give in a card he won in a previous round.

When the drawing deck is empty the game stops. The player with the most cards wins the game.

boardgame.name: Arkana Miłości
boardgame.description:
Arkana Miłości (Arcana of Love) is an exclusive erotic card game for couples who are not afraid of new challenges.

This best-selling Polish game is close to the LCG format (living card game). In the basic box you can find 55 cards and a rule booklet. During the gameplay the participants have 5 kinds of cards (arcana, challenges, actions, counter-actions and special actions)at their disposal. Every person has 5 cards on hand and can use three of them in any combination. The game ends when one of the players (the game was designed for an unlimited number of players, but of course it will be played mostly by couples) is naked and an "arcana" card is played.

So far one expansion pack has been published, with more to come in the future.

Polish description from the publisher:

Arkana Miłości to bestseller na rynku gier partnerskich. Celem gry jest wzmacnianie relacji między zauroczonymi sobą osobami oraz efektywne urozmaicanie stałych związków. boardgame.name: Orphée: Voyage aux Enfers
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Night is falling, you're tired, it's raining and you're eager to get home soon so you go a little too fast on the highway. A deafening sound, a bone-crushing shock, the smell of burning rubber and you wake up in a damp cavern. You're in Hell, and Satan offers you a deal: if you can bring him a suitable gift, He'll let you live and your soul will be returned to your body. If you fail, you'll have all Eternity to think about speed limits and safety belts...

Orphée is a graphical text adventure game. It uses a text parser for player input and a vector graphics. It's a classic adventure-game, with inventory-based puzzles and a lot of ways to "die": thirst is a common way to die (Hell is supposed to be a hot place after all) and the player must be careful to always have drinking water handy.

The game features an important number of locations, a lot of characters (some of them can accompany the player) and digitized voice samples used to give the player vital clues.

boardgame.name: Skweek
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Skweek is an arcade-puzzle game, the first of a series. The Skweeks are little furry balls who lived happily on their pink planet until the evil Pitark came and repainted each of the 99 continents blue. Now Pitark is dead and a young Skweek has decided to celebrate by repainting the world in its original color. But Pitark's minions are still here, and each continent has its own hazards and dangers.

The player controls a Skweek, the goal is to clear each of the 99 levels by painting each tile pink by walking on it. The Skweek can shoot bullets to destroy monsters (they respawn after a few seconds) and can pickup a number of power-ups like a stronger laser than can destroy walls, shoes to walk on ice, bonus items... Each level has its specific dangers to overcome and monster behavior can change between levels (there are levels where monsters can paint back tiles in blue, others in which they can build additional tiles over the water). Each level has a time limit. The player can earn extra lives by picking up Baby Skweeks or scoring points.

Like other Loriciels action-puzzle games, the game levels can be played either sequentially or in random order.

boardgame.name: Demon City Shinjuku Role Playing Game and Resource Book
boardgame.description:
From the Back Cover:

Tokyo. The turn of the millennium. The glittering skyline, which once rivaled any in the world, lies cracked and crumbling under the weight of an oppressive evil. One man, the tyrannical Levih Rah, has created a Demon City in Shinjuku, the heart of Tokyo. That's just the beginning. Rah's mission is to destroy the world by opening a gate to the Demon Void, which will turn Earth into a living Hell. In three days, the world as we know it will be no longer.

Hope. For years, no one had dared to enter the city infested by Rah's evil minions - until now. Desperate to save the life of her captured father, the beautiful Sayaka Rama ventures into Shinjuku with the aid of Kyoya Izayoi, a Tokyo teenager skilled in the mysterious martial art of Nenpo. With assistance from a cynical and aged mystic, a streetwise youth, and an enigmatic spiritual healer, Kyoya and Sayaka might actually have a chance to defeat the dark sorcerer, Rah...

This role-playing game is based on the popular feature-length 1988 Japanese animated action-adventure horror film, from the original work of Hideyuki Kikuchi. You can now join the fight against the dark powers of Levih Rah, or be a part of the demon hordes that terrorize Shinjuku. The game features the intuitive and easy-to-learn Tri-Stat System game mechanics, which is fully compatible with Guardians of Order's other anime role-playing games. Additionally, the book offers extensive resources and references and for Demon City Shinjuku fans (including an extensive movie summary and detailed character bios), and a full-color gallery of spectacular animation art. The ideal role-playing game for fans of Japanese anime, or occult-gothic horror.

boardgame.name: Casefile: ZODIAC
boardgame.description:
Publisher's Description:

A Free RPG - Weird 1970's Espionage

Behind the velour wallpaper, under the bean bag, crouching in the grimy recesses of the shag pile carpet there is strangeness. A deep, messed up kind of strangeness that goes beyond the mind altering effects of macramé? or the strange popularity of the Bay City Rollers. You may live your grim 9 to 5 life, worry about the energy crisis, worry about the bomb, worry about freaks and punks next door but what you really should be worried about are the things you don't even know exist.

I am talking about aliens without fashion, big crime, 18 degree angels, funk sucking ghosts, discotheque gods, Agents of D.I.R.T., demonic swinger parasites. All these and more. The worst thing is they are organized, they call themselves ASTROLABUS and their plans for the future do not involve you. If they had their way, you won t be here to see the eighties in. That nice new suburb of yours? Just a death camp with lawn ornaments.

But, what do you know, we are organized too. Since the late fifties we have come to know about them (all the different thems). At first we were castigated, called nuts, the men in white coats came like seagulls on a sandwich. But slowly and surely we made connections, found out there were others who had seen what we had seen. Most of us came from the espionage scene, it was our business to go poking around where no one was meant to be. But we made other allies too, occultists, mad, er fringe scientists, ecologists, hustlers and funk cosmonauts.

We knew the world was in trouble. We knew no one else was going to do anything. Steve McQueen is dead. We formed ZODIAC.

boardgame.name: Vintage
boardgame.description:
Vintage is about the Douro River Valley of Portugal, the oldest demarcated wine producing region in the world, designated World Heritage, and the production of port wine. Each player will attempt to buy wine-growing estates and plant them with the best grape varieties to try and produce the highest quality port wine - a VINTAGE.

This game has a simple version and a normal version. The simple version is aimed at players who are not used to this kind of family strategy games. The game has fewer options and a higher degree of luck. It plays faster and is easy to learn.

With the normal version you will discover the VINTAGE game in its fullness, with many more strategic options and where luck plays a minor role. It’s a longer and more challenging game but with only slightly more complex rules. Cheers!

boardgame.name: The Fate of Inglemia (D20)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Welcome to the Fate of Inglemia!

This Strategic Campaign outline features a Very High Magic setting for Very High Level characters. It is designed to allow the characters to alter events on a world shattering level. Incorporating elements of the Elemental Dimension of Magic, Inglemia goes back to the Prime Material roots of the eternal conflict between the Jeshatan and the magic hating Knah'tan.

Includes: 144 Spells, 9 Monsters, 12 Exotic Materials, 28 Unique Magic Items, 7 Gods, 19 Unique Feats, 20 Noble Houses, 10 Secret Societies, 7 Gods, 12 Unique Kingdoms, Self Replicating Runes, Mirror Tubes, and 5 Strategic Session Summaries!

From Introduction:

The Fate of Inglemia is not a module. It is a product designed to give the GM a primer to establish a set of parameters for an Epic campaign involving the City State of Inglemia and its encounter with their ancient cousins, the Jeshatan of the Elemental Dimension of Magic. This product incorporates elements from the products The Elemental Dimension of Magic.

Thematically speaking, the game is designed for characters of around 15th level, allowing them to go up in level every two sessions well into the epic levels and beyond. While it is certainly possible to use this product for a low level game, the GM also has the tools to allow his players to be movers and shakers on a primal level.

While the core strategic campaign was originally designed to have the players be agents that defend Inglemia, they could just as easily be agents bent on its destruction. Inglemia certainly is not without plenty of enemies nor is it without flaw. While it is a fantastic place, there is still rot at the core and it is primed for change; whether good or ill is up to the players…and you.

boardgame.name: Secrets of the Knah'tan
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

Long divergent from their cousins, the Jeshatan, the Knah’tan hate all forms of magic. They strive to destroy it from all existence. They have several methods of doing this, foremost among them is their paramount craftsmanship. However, they also maintain a fervent breeding program which has led to increased intelligence and physical strength over the millennia. Still, these two are not quite enough; for their true deadly power lies with psionics and supremely potent alchemical concoctions.

They are a firm and merciless race. They prize logic and reason above all other things, but despite this face emotional rages and irrationalities that they refuse to acknowledge. To call a Knah’tan an irrational fool is an unforgivable insult that must be met with violence or social shame. Knah’tan politics is quite labyrinthine and often involves whispering campaigns and grudges that go on for centuries.

There are spells and there are spells. The Jeshatan are masters of magic in many areas, but their supremacy in the realm of magic is paramount about all. For them, it is not merely a way of life, but of survival, for the harsh conditions of the Elemental Dimension of Magic would quickly render them dead unless they took extreme measures to protect themselves from it. boardgame.name: ScrumBrawl
boardgame.description:
ScrumBrawl is a board game where players control fantastic creatures vying for supremacy within the Arena, scoring goals by maneuvering various types of enchanted orbs into portals set within the Arena or fighting other creatures to the death to prevent them from reaching the portals. The 100-card deck contains fifty creatures with different characteristics that determine how the creature interacts with the orbs (throw accuracy, catching ability, and throwing range), how fast a creature can move, and how effective it is in battle. Many creatures also have unique magic abilities that can be used to manipulate gameplay.

When players summon creatures, corresponding creature tokens (miniature cards that stand erect in cardstands) enter the 20x20 square gameboard, known as the Arena, where the orb and portal tokens await the contestants. In a four-player game, players may compete in teams of two. Goals are scored by creatures that maneuver an orb token onto a portal token by picking up, carrying, handing off, and throwing the orb with their creature tokens. Additionally, players can score goals (known as Skins) by successfully destroying opponents' creatures in combat. Combat results are determined by dice rolls as are the success of throws and catches of the orb between creatures. A number of Alter Reality cards allow players to change the values of individual rolls which make the outcome of every roll something that can quickly be challenged.

Enchantment cards can be played on creatures to grant them enhanced stats or new abilities as well as make them hardier in combat. Event cards, such a Lightning Storms or Fumbles can change the flow the game in seconds forcing players to constantly rethink their strategies for scoring or engaging in combat.

The game ends when a player or team reaches three goals, one of which must be a non-skins goal. No lead is safe and no two matches are ever the same making each game a unique and often humorous experience. The name is the combination of Scrum (a Rugby term where players strive for possession of the ball) and Brawl (a roaring fight, in our case, to the death). ScrumBrawl is the inaugural title for VicTim Games LLC.

Game time ranges from 20-40 minutes for a 2 player game, 30-45 minutes for a 3 player game, and 40-60 minutes for a 4 player game.

boardgame.name: Necronomicon
The Necronomicon Horror
Necronomicon Redux
boardgame.description:
The Necronomicon Horror invites fans of fantasy and horror role-playing games to immerse themselves in the nightmarish world of Jazz-age author H.P. Lovecraft, widely considered to be the father of modern horror.

The Necronomicon Horror is a single-player game of arcane horror and mystery, created by Dustin Neff, and designed to evoke the feeling of a role-playing campaign and board game. Players take on the roles of investigators in an attempt to thwart the evil machinations of a sinister cult who have stolen the Necronomicon from Miskatonic Universities library, and have used it to open the gateway to another dimension--threatening the entire world.

The Necronomicon Horror combines the quick, easy to learn, addictive pace of fantasy card games, combined with the strategy of table-top role-playing and board games. You can win achievements in the game to unlock new bonus content, and there will be support for downloadable expansions in the future.

During the game you’ll take on a variety of personas, becoming both investigators and innocents swept up in a battle against cosmic horrors. With the help of allies, weapons, secret information, strategy, and a few twists-of-fate, you’ll attempt to stop the minions of Cthulhu from entering our world.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Lee Trevino's Fighting Golf
boardgame.description:
Lee Trevino's Fighting Golf is an alternating one to four-player arcade game released by SNK in 1988.

A player can choose between four different golfers, each one having his or her own advantages and disadvantages. Lee Trevino is playable as a character named Super Mex. Despite the title, no fighting is involved in the game. Other characters are Pretty Amy, Miracle Chosuke and Big Jumbo. Pretty Amy is not as strong, but easier to control. Miracle Chosuke and Super Mex are somewhat in the middle. Big Jumbo has the best range, but the worst control (in this game, "control" refers to the length of the aiming guide).

The game play was relatively simplistic, completely devoid of the storylines and off-field strategizing common of sports games today. The player had to avoid sand traps, water hazards, rough ground and trees.

The courses themselves ranged from relatively straight-forward fairways to elaborate arrangements of sand traps. There were two courses, Japan and the U.S.. The U.S. course main hazards were its placement of bunkers and super rough. The Japan course main hazards were water and going out of bounds.

At the end of the game, the player was greeted with a photorealistic shot of the country club lodge against the setting sun and surrounded by trees.

Source: Wikipedia, "Lee Trevino's Fighting Golf", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Firearms, Rituals, and Artifacts - Oh My

Tools may be the key to winning the Aeon War. For some, they are the advanced weapons created by companies like Armorcorp or Colt Springfield. For others, they are the magically-imbued objects that they create while intoning powerful forces in darkened mystical spaces. For still others, they are the ancient and lost artifacts for which they search the dark corners of the Earth. To the Ashcroft Foundation, they are the children of arcanotechnology - the melding of science and the arcane.

This is the Aeon War. Carry a weapon.

Explore the world of modern firearms, armor, and explosives, digging into their vital characteristics. Find out what sorts of wondrous everyday tools might be waiting. Expand the utility of those sorcerers who choose the path of enchanter with a host of new rituals. Hold onto ancient legacies through the revelation of ancient artifacts. Discover the many manifestations of Ashcroft’s arcanotechnology. See what alien mysteries belong to both the Migou and the Esoteric Order of Dagon.

Nowhere else will you find a setting like this.

Expanded and revised weapons of all kinds.

boardgame.name: Harlequin Checkers
boardgame.description:
From Zillions of Games

"Pieces move diagonally but capture orthogonally. This is so as to combine the forced progression of diagonal checkers with the richness of the orthogonal game.

Object: Capture all your opponent's pieces ("Checkers" or "Kings") by jumping over them, or stalemate the opponent so he has no moves.

Checkers can move diagonally forward, by sliding to an adjacent empty square or by jumping either left, right, or forward over an enemy piece to a vacant square on the other side. Jumping over a piece captures it, but you may not jump diagonally. Capturing is mandatory, and you must keep jumping and capturing as long as it is possible, taking the maximum number of pieces.

The King is a long range piece and can slide diagonally in any direction or jump left, right, up or down over any opponent piece to any free square. When your Checker stops on the other end of the board, it becomes a King and can then also move backwards. If it merely visits a promotion square during a series capture moves, then it does not promote."

boardgame.name: Hopperdame
boardgame.description:
From Hopperdame website ( http://mlwi.magix.net/bg/hopperdame.htm )

HopperDame (or simply Hoppers) is a new invention. In HopperDame with promotion rule you win by capturing all the opponent's pieces. Pieces move forwards and sideways, orthogonally or diagonally, by shifting to an adjacent square, or by jumping over an adjacent friendly piece (also termed 'hopper'). Jumps must only occur over a piece of the same colour. It's not allowable to step or jump backwards. The exception to this is the "king", which can jump over any piece, and step in all directions.

To promote to king one must conquer the "castles", that is, the corner squares behind the enemy position, by holding both these positions with a piece, so called "double-promotion". If a piece steps or jumps into the enemy corner then it is promoted to king only if the other enemy corner is already occupied by a friendly piece. Also, a piece which steps into the corner square may later be promoted if the other corner has subsequently become occupied by a friendly piece. The promotion is then done by dropping the piece on the same square. But this costs a move.

HopperDame employs the rule of exchange-capture: the counter jumps over a friendly counter. If the square where it lands is occupied by an enemy counter, then this is captured. It is only when leaping that the counter can make captures. A leaping counter may continue to leap over friendly counters until there are no more to leap over or the player decides to stop. It's not allowable to jump back to the square you just came from.

Note that capture is only made when jumping. Thus, a single piece cannot make a capture by itself. The exception to this is the king, which has an additional capture method: it can capture an adjacent enemy piece directly, like a king in chess.

boardgame.description:
SUMMARY:

Poker Face is a board game of betting/wagering, not Lady Gaga, and money can NOT be used in playing the game. Each game consists of 7 matches. In the beginning of each match, a Match Card is drawn. Players follow the steps on the card to prepare the match, place bets and play action cards to alter the result in their favors. When the objective meets after playing rounds of action cards, the match ends. The winners receive points and the losers may receive penalty based on their bets. After 7 matches, player with the highest score wins the game.

COMPONENTS:

Board x 1
Objective Cards x 8
Action Cards x 108
Starting Player token x 1
Player token x 24
Power token x 8
Game Round marker x 1
Rule x 1







1) First edition is Simplified Chinese.
2) There are 36 types of action card, based on the ancient Chinese 36 stratagems.

boardgame.name: The Elemental Dimension of Magic
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

In order to understand a dimension composed entirely of magic, one first has to define it. Every world has its own definition and manifestation. Indeed, more often than not a resident god controls the threads of the arcane and radiates them through the fabric of the time. Yet, magic seems to transcend these origins. When gods die, their magic often lingers. Magic manifests in more than a dozen forms, but, in the end, it is still magic.

It is easy to point out fire as an element. We see it about us every day, just as we see water, or the blowing wind and most certainly earth. Magic warps and twists and follows the commands of those who call upon it.
Yet, at the same time, it works upon the world. Magic seems to know what it is doing, yet has no direct mind of its own. It transcends definition and limitation. Attempts to bottle it and place boundaries upon it, saying "Here then lie the boundaries of what is the Arcane," fail time and again. Indeed, with magic, more often than not, the only consistent rule is that whatever rules you establish will eventually be broken.

This is the manifestation of magic. It breaks rules. It binds logic and forces it through a tiny mesh of human understanding. It pretends to follow pattern and format, but in the end those who use it end up dust and it continues flowing. Gods die; mortals fade; entire races become extinct and, yet, the magic remains. This, then, is how one defines an element. Magic is a fundamental building block of the universe, as basic a part of existence as anything else.

What is it? Ultimately, magic is whatever you want it to be, literally. On the sunken world of Deris‐bar, magic only works in proper conjunction with the stars. On the world of Lykra‐han, magic works only by patient blood sacrifice of a willing subject. In the world of the Throne of the Emerald Dawn, magic flows as freely as air, and all wield it to one degree or another. Each realm has separate rules that govern its magic, generally regulated through the will of powerful minds manifested as gods. And yet leave them, and quite often their rules cease to apply. Paradoxically, despite having different rules governing its nature from realm to realm, magic often produces identical effects in each, such as fireballs and lightning bolts.

Шахбол
boardgame.description:
Shahbol is a cross between chess and football.
The game is played on a field size of 5x8 cells. Gates occupy the first and last row of the field.
Each player has 7 pieces: 3 forwards, 3 defense and a goalie, another figure depicts the ball. Players move the one piece per turn, trying to send the ball into the opponent's gate.

boardgame.name: 101 Legendary Treasures of Medieval Europe
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

From the Spear of Destiny to the Shroud of Turin.

From the Holy Tunic of Jacque De Molay to the Staff of Merlin.

From the Horn of Roland to the Sword of St. Peter.

101 Legendary Treasures of Medieval Europe is a 40-page landscape format PDF packed with a variety of treasures suitable for any D20 campaign set in Earth's historical and magical past.

This material can be easily introduced into any D20 fantasy campaign and, for those with an interest in the occult, any supernatural/weird D20 Modern campaign.

boardgame.name: 101 Mundane Treasures Revised
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

From the author of 101 Spellbooks comes another batch of treasure items. Every gamemaster has hundreds of magical items to choose from when distributing treasure but how many mundane items are available?

This book helps remedy that minor problem. With 101 treasure items, each one written specifically for this book, gamemasters may now start adding various mundane armors, shields, articles of clothing, pieces of jewelry, and even weapons to the treasure hoards their players find.

While players may find the contents of this 26-page book interesting, it is the gamemasters who will really benefit from the items within.
